children.text: Content Standard 1: The student shall demonstrate knowledge of art from ancient civilizations.

Identify characteristics of art and terminology related to art produced by ancient civilizations (e.g., Prehistoric, Sumerian, Babylonian, Assyrian, Egyptian, Asian, African, Mid-Eastern, Pacific, the Americas)
Identify architecture and artwork of ancient civilizations

Recognize various influences (e.g., social, cultural, geographical, environmental, political, spiritual, economical, technological, architectural, literature, music, performing arts) on art and design of ancient civilizations
Identify the impact of art and design of ancient civilizations on that society and future societies
Identify media and processes found in the artwork of ancient civilizations
Identify themes that appear in the artwork of ancient civilizations (e.g., universal, societal, individual)
Analyze the artwork and designs of ancient civilizations (e.g., creative intentions, styles, symbols, purposes for creating)
Content Standard 2: The student shall demonstrate knowledge of art from classic civilizations.
Identify characteristics of art and terminology related to art produced by classic civilizations (e.g., Dorian, Ionian, Hellenic, Greek, Etruscan, Roman, early Byzantine)
Identify artists, artworks, and architecture of classic civilizations (e.g., Phidias, Myron, Praxiteles, Parthenon, Coliseum, Pantheon)

Recognize various influences (e.g., social, cultural, geographical, environmental, political, spiritual, economical, technological, architectural, music, literature, performing arts) on art and design of classic civilizations
Identify the impact of art and design of classic civilizations on that society and future societies
Identify media and processes found in the artwork of classic civilizations
Identify themes that appear in the artwork of classic civilizations (e.g., universal, societal, individual)
Analyze the artwork and designs of classic civilizations (e.g., creative intentions, styles, symbols, purposes for creating)
Explore artwork produced throughout the rest of the world (e.g., Asia, Africa, Pacific, the Americas)
Content Standard 3: The student shall demonstrate knowledge of art from the Middle Ages.

Identify characteristics of art and terminology related to art produced during the Middle Ages (e.g., Dark Ages, Romanesque, Celtic, Saxon, Hiberno, late Byzantine, Justinian, Islamic, Carolingian, Gothic, High Gothic)
Identify artists, artworks, and architecture of the Middle Ages (e.g., Giotto, Cimabue, illuminated manuscripts, Book of Kells)

Recognize various influences (e.g., social, cultural, geographical, environmental, political, spiritual, economical, technological, architectural, literature, music, performing arts) on art and design of the Middle Ages
Identify the impact of art and design of the Middle Ages on that society and future societies
Identify media and processes found in the artwork of the Middle Ages
Identify themes that appear in the artwork of the Middle Ages (e.g., universal, societal, individual)
Analyze the artwork and designs of the Middle Ages (e.g., creative intentions, styles, symbols, purposes for creating)
Explore artwork produced throughout the rest of the world (e.g., Asia, Africa, Pacific, the Americas)
Content Standard 4: The student shall demonstrate knowledge of art from the Early and High Renaissance.
Identify characteristics of art and terminology related to art produced during the Early and High Renaissance (e.g., Italian, European)

Identify artists, artworks, and architecture of the Early and High Renaissance (e.g., Botticelli, Leonardo da Vinci, Masaccio, Michelangelo, Raphael, Donatello, the Mona Lisa, the Sistine Chapel, St. Peter's Cathedral, Ste. Maria della Fiori Cathedral, the Birth of Venus, the Piet√†)

Recognize various influences on art and design of the Early and High Renaissance (e.g., social, cultural, geographical, environmental, political, spiritual, economical, technological, architectural, literature, music, performing arts)
Identify the impact of art and design of the Early and High Renaissance on that society and future societies
Identify media and processes found in the artwork of the Early and High Renaissance
Identify themes that appear in the artwork of the Early and High Renaissance (e.g., universal, societal, individual)
Analyze the artwork and designs of the Early and High Renaissance (e.g., creative intentions, styles, symbols, purposes for creating)
Explore artwork produced throughout the rest of the world (e.g., Asia, Africa, Pacific, the Americas)
